Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Developing Organic Photoconductive Materials through Modular Design of Self-Assembling Components
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry supports Joseph J. Reczek of Denison University in this project to design, synthesize and characterize new donor-acceptor columnar liquid crystals as organic electronic materials. The approach involves development of synthetic methodologies for the generation of highly substituted aromatic compounds with the ability to self-assemble into a variety of ordered, functional materials. The optical and electrical properties of these fundamentally new materials will be investigated towards novel components for photovoltaics and other optoelectronic applications.

This project will engage a cohort of undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research at Denison University, a primarily undergraduate institution. These students will be trained in cutting-edge techniques and instrumentation related to several branches of chemistry, including organic synthesis, molecular self-assembly, materials chemistry, and device fabrication. Students will gain experience in teamwork, leadership, and project management, as well as giving scientific presentations in the local community and at national conferences. New instrumentation supported will broadly affect research and teaching at Denison. The proposed work could significantly impact the fields of self-assembly, organic electronic materials, and photovoltaics, while training undergraduate students for success in scientific careers and post-graduate education as well as raising awareness of alternative energy research in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes resulting from the projects and activities of this grant award have had an important impact on advancing scientific knowledge, capabilities, and training in the United States. Fourteen Denison University undergraduate students were directly engaged in this research. All of these students are currently pursuing scientific or medical careers, including six who are enrolled in science PhD programs, with three more in the process of applying. As further evidence of the high quality research experience and training of participating students, three have recently been awarded prestigious NSF-GFRP fellowships (Annelise Thompson, Ariana Gray Be, and Riley Sechrist). Additionally, four high school students from Licking County, OH were engaged in this research, and each is currently enrolled in or applying to an undergraduate college with an intention to focus in the sciences. These student outcomes highlight the high societal value of the research training resulting from this grant award.

The research supported by this grant award has resulted in two high-quality publications to date, including seven undergraduate coauthors, with at least three more publications to be published in the near future. The general focus of this research has been on the design, synthesis, and study of organic compounds towards new types of materials with properties of interest for future technologies, including solar cells and wearable tech. The materials we focused on, termed donor-acceptor columnar liquid crystals (DACLCs), are formed from the combination of two complementary aromatic molecules. When melted together, the two different molecules organize in an alternating fashion, or “self-assemble,” to make materials that can have completely different characteristics from the original components, such as strong absorption of sunlight and semiconducting properties. With this approach, multiple component molecules can be “mixed-and-matched” in a modular approach to generating many materials with fine-tuned properties in a relatively straight-forward and low-cost process.

One publication from this work describes advances in the synthetic techniques for making some of the aromatic components used in forming DACLCs and other important organic materials. We developed new methods for acquiring key compounds, achieving almost double the efficiency of previously reported approaches. The second publication offers new insight into the structural control and tuning of DACLC materials, and reveals a newly discovered property, the ability to form DACLC films that interact differently with light depending on the film orientation. We show that certain DACLC materials can make almost perfectly “dichroic” films, behaving similarly to polarizing sunglasses. In contrast to traditional polarizers, these small-molecule films are easily tuned, can self-heal, and have the potential to act as inherent semiconducting materials of potential use in new types of displays, sensors, and solar cells. In addition to this published work, we have made significant progress toward developing the syntheses of new anthracene and anthraquinone molecules with potential use in both materials science and biomedical applications, and we have also begun the successful incorporation of DACLC materials into new solar cell devices. The outcomes of this grant award will continue to have a significant impact on research and research training in the Reczek Group, and on the development of new functional organic-based materials by modular design.
